statement.text: There is NO fundamental minimum frequency—electromagnetic waves can have arbitrarily low frequencies (long wavelengths). The lowest radio waves used are ELF (Extremely Low Frequency) at 3-30 Hz for submarine communication. Gravitational wave searches probe nanohertz (10⁻⁹ Hz) via pulsar timing. A 'year wave' has f = 1/(365.25×86400) ≈ 3×10⁻⁸ Hz. The Planck frequency (fₚ ≈ 1.9 × 10⁴³ Hz) is a MAXIMUM, not minimum.
statement.formal: No minimum: f → 0 is allowed; ELF radio: 3-30 Hz; Pulsar timing: ~10⁻⁹ Hz; Planck: 1.9 × 10⁴³ Hz (maximum)

explanation.intuition: Frequency can be arbitrarily low because wavelength can be arbitrarily long. A wave with a 1-year period has f ≈ 30 nHz. Pulsar timing arrays search for gravitational waves with periods of years. The Planck frequency represents the MAXIMUM meaningful oscillation rate—one cycle per Planck time. Above this, quantum gravity effects dominate.
explanation.key_insight: The practical limit on low frequencies is measurement time: to measure frequency f precisely, you need observation time t >> 1/f. NANOGrav and similar experiments have observed for ~15 years, probing ~10⁻⁹ Hz gravitational waves.

comparison_with_planck.interpretation: Planck frequency is MAXIMUM—the highest possible oscillation rate. There is no minimum frequency.

related.relationship: Planck frequency is MAXIMUM, not minimum
E = hf connects energy and frequency
